(Don't worry explanation is optional and you can skip it by playing the game in Flat Earther variant.) Each conspiracy card gives a special ability to its believer. Use it wisely to become more influential than your rivals and their childish tales.

In Conspiracy, each player acts simultaneously during the two rounds of a turn. There are three types of action they can choose from: action card drawing, playing an action card, and flipping a news card. Action cards give you some useful abilities and influence among the believers. The most influential wins the actual news (card) at the end of the turn. By your clairvoyance ability, you can flip your news cards to see the hidden message between the lines and get a useful bonus.

A player wins and the game ends when any player reaches the given number of followers and is able to keep them until the end of the turn.

Conspiracy offers a cooperative and a solo mode as well where you can work together (or alone) to uncover the shadow government before it's too late. Merge your conspiracy cards to the ultimate great grandfathers of all conspiracy theories and play action cards side by side against the shadow government cards to win the actual news (card), protect your theory and your hands.

In cooperative mode, the game ends when the players reach the given number of followers and keep them until the end of the turn or when the shadow government deck is depleted.

The core mechanics of the game are: hand management, flipping a card, bid, tableau building, variable player powers, and narrative building.

Name: My Words Are Better Than Yours
Description:
This game is a card-based adaptation of Scrabble game-play. The deck has 69 letter cards, a majority of which are basic cards and just have a letter score.  For each vowel, there are 3 basic cards, and one each of x2, x3, and x4 letter score cards, which multiply adjacent consonants in their word by that amount.  There are also 15 consonant cards that multiply the score for the entire word by x2, x3, or x4.

Each player is dealt an 8-card hand. On their turn, a player plays a word from their hand that must use one basic card from the previous player's word if there is one; they tally the word's score and then draw to fill their hand back to 8 cards. A player may also just pass and draw one card.

The game ends after the deck runs out and all players pass in turn. The highest total score wins the game.

Name: Chachapoya: SNAKE Adventurer Promo Cards II
Description:
The base Chachapoya game is expanded by 2 new different adventurer cards. We shuffle the SNAKE Adventurer promo cards into the adventurer's deck, then prepare the other cards as its written in the game rules.

THE BLUFF: The player leads The BLUFF card and immadiately collects all the played money that the players have already bet.

THE PARASITE: The player leads The Parasite card and chooses one player who has to discard one of the played adventurer cards. The attacked player takes all of their cards back and bets again.

Enjoy playing the game and have fun with treasure hunting!

Name: 王宮の飾り絵師 (Painter in the Royal Palace)
Description:
In çŽ‹å®®ã®é£¾ã‚Šçµµå¸« (ÅŒkyÅ« No Kazari Eshi), roughly translated as Royal Palace Decorative Painter, the players are each painters who have been hired by the royal family to paint the Monochrome Palace.

Each player receives a die showing different colors and one showing different numbers.  The players also get a sheet which shows the outline of a painting which they will be coloring in during the game.

On a turn, the players simultaneously choose the faces for their dice and then reveal.  Beginning with players who chose the smaller number, players can color in sections on their sheet corresponding to the number and color chosen as their dice values.  However, as the resolution proceeds to higher valued die, you will not be able to fill in colors that were chosen by players with lower numbers, and other similar concerns.

The game includes royal request cards that can grant points at the end of the game (e.g. have the most sectors of a certain color) or during the game (e.g. be the first do have one section of each color).

The game ends after 12 rounds, and the player with the most points wins.

Name: Countin' Sheep Card Game Combo
Description:
This is a pair of children's card games to celebrate and advertise the release of Cadaco's Countin' Sheep line of plushy sheep dolls. The games are:

Sheep Sweep

A version of Crazy 8s. In turn each player plays a card that matches the previous card in either color or name of the plushy  doll on the card. If no play is possible, they draw a card and play it if possible.  Lucky cards can change the color; Sleep cards make the player to your right skip their next turn. The first player to play all their cards wins.

Go Graze

A version of Go Fish.  There are four cards for each of 13 ranks. In their turn a player asks another player for cards of a certain rank; if they have any they must give them all, otherwise they say "Go graze" and the asker draws a card, showing and counting it if it's the requested rank.  A successful play lets the player play again. A complete set of 4 of a rank are placed on the table. After all the cards are placed in sets, the player with the most sets wins.

Name: Crown & Crescent
Description:
The American victory at Saratoga in 1777 and their Treaty with France in 1778 transformed the war in America. The potential influx of fresh French troops to swell the ranks of General Washington’s Army drove the British to rethink their colonial strategy. As a result the British moved their efforts from the middle colonies to the southern colonies where it was believed sentiment for the crown’s cause ran strong. Having secured Savannah in 1779 the British turned their eyes on Charleston and South Carolina. When the British crossed the Savannah River South Carolina became the focal point of the revolution.

The years, 1780-1781, in South Carolina saw some of the most intense fighting that occurred in the revolution as both Loyalists and Patriots both rose up in numbers to fight for or against the crown. The struggle for independence during those two years saw over 200+ actions, skirmishes, and battles fought in South Carolina resulting in the names of Marion, Morgan, and Tarleton and places such as Kings Mountain and Cowpens entering American lore.

Crown and Crescent models the two years of intense, fierce fighting in South Carolina adopting and modifying the unique and innovative command and control mechanics created by the Ragnar Brothers for ANGOLA!  These mechanics keep players guessing, create plenty of tension, and reward the right balance of boldness and caution as you guide your forces towards independence or crushing the revolting colonists. The map is divided into seven districts, encompassing 6 to 7 key locations each, used to show control of the district. Control enough key locations and you’ll then control the district and therefore advance on the victory point track towards winning the game.

The counters represent military units and auxiliaries such as artillery, rifled and light troops, grenadiers, dragoons, and cavalry. A unique command and activation system has players planning in secret the order in which they will activate a limited number of their units for the turn. The players then take turns activating their units in the determined order. The result is a tense game, with players trying to analyze the map and out guess their enemies.

Crown and Crescent can be played with between two to four players (Continental and Whigs vs British and Tories).

Components:

        One 22”x34” full-color map
        Two full sheets of counters (352 5/8" counters)
        One full color rule book
        One deck of 55 cards
        4 player aid cards
        20 dice


—description from the publisher

Name: Interval Initiate
Description:
In Interval Initiate, players clash in 3 epic rounds of Note playing and Interval claiming! At the start of each round, each player drafts an Initiate card and draws Note cards equal to the combined health of all the Initiates on their team.
During each round, players take turns placing Note cards to either the left or right Notes stacks. Be the fastest to SLAP the correct Interval card that matches the interval between the Note cards to claim it! Beware, slapping the wrong Interval causes you to lose Notes! The player with the most intervals at the end of 3 rounds wins!

—description from the publisher

Name: Lord of the Chords: Who Let The Chords Out? – 2nd Booster Pack: Composers
Description: What is the best way to commemorate the greatest classical composers of all time? Pun-ify their names and crack jokes about their past of course! It's your Rachmanin-off day! Ravel in the Satie-sfaction of not needing to go Bach to work with puns that you'll never be Hayden!

Name: Lord of the Chords: Who Let The Chords Out? – 3rd Booster Pack: Modulation
Description: Crank complexity up to the maximum with the Modulation pack's new game mechanic; Cadences! Only true music theorists can harness the power of the cadence and slay the composition! Those who lack practice will be revealed! All will be enlightened!

Name: Lord of the Chords: Who Let The Chords Out? – 4th Booster Pack: Essentials
Description: The Essentials pack introduces an additional card type; the Equip! Aimed to serve every musician's favorite pastime; buying new music equipment! Equip them onto your instrument to augment your playstyle and diminish our foes!

Name: Lord of the Chords: Who Let The Chords Out? – 5th Booster Pack: Conductor
Description: This Conductor pack introduces us to a new car type; Styles! Just like how a conductor influences the way every musician in the orchestra plays the music, Style cards influences the way every player plays the game! But unlike conductors, Style cards will never get angry when you are out of tune. Never.
